Condi· ciones, quae ad praeteritum vel ad praesens tempus res · runtur, aut statim infirmant obligationem aut omnino non differunt: veluti ‘si Titius consul suit' vel ‘si Maevius vivit, dare spondesi’ nam si ea ita non sunt, nihil valet stipulatio: sin autem ita se habent, statim valet. quae enim per rerum naturam certa sunt, non morantur obligationem, licet apud nos incerta sint.

An obligation may possibly be performable only in one place, as happens often in connection with immoveable property. ln some cases again (asin the text) the place at which performance should be made is fixed, either expressly or by implication, by the parties. lf this is so, the dehtor is neither bound nor entitled to perform elsewhere, though, ii the action by which the obligation was pursued was bonae fidei (or even stricti iuris, il demanding a iacere) the creditor might sue elsewhere, the advantage or disadvantage accruing to the defendant being taken into account in fixing the damages. When the obligation was to convey (dare) a definite object or quantitas at a definite place, this could not be done until aiter the introduction oi the praetorian arbitraria actio ‘de eo quod certo loco dari oportet,' Bk. iv. 6. 31 and 33 ini. ln all other cases (i.e. where no place was fixed sor the periormance), the debtor was entitled to perform wherever he iound the creditor, unless the place was bonafide inconvenient, Dig. 46. 3. 39, and was bound to perform at any place in which, should he refusa, the creditor actually obtained ajudg· ment against him. The only exceptione to this are (r) that an heir cannot be compelled to pay legacies elsewhere than where the greater part of the inheritance is, Dig. 5. 1.4o pr, (2) that where a man has to deliver a specific thing or quantity, he cannot be compelled todo this elsewhere than where the thing or quantity actually is, unless the creditor will take the risk and pay the cust of removal, Dig. 4. 1. 38.
